I love it when my paintings surprise me and go in a direction that I never could have anticipated! 

I saw @derek_klena & @iamjojo in @moulinrougebway 🎭in May, and was blown about by their performance. 

There is such a difference between seeing a photo of a performer and actually having the chance to see them IRL. I absolutely believe that experience completely changes your painting, in a way that enriches your interpretation tremendously. 

I started this painting on an @art.prof live stream with no intention of it being more than a demo sketch.

I don’t usually go back and finish pieces from live stream demos, and if I do, it’s minimal. 

When it comes to Moulin Rouge though, which has taken care over my studio practice, it’s hard for me to leave even a simple sketch alone! 

The more paintings I make, the more I see the vast potential with each one, and this one was no exception.

I guess I have always seen rhinestone 💎stickers as a silly craft supply that I would never use. In retrospect, that’s a ridiculous assumption for me to make about an art supply. 

Materials are markers, acrylic inks, acrylic paint, colored pencil, and rhinestone stickers on Rives BFK paper. 

Reference is from video of a 📸photo shoot by @murphymade and @evzmm from @moulinrougebway

Why you should always ask for what you want: when I traveled to NYC to see @moulinrougebway for the commission, (you’ll see it Fri!) I asked if I could get access to sketch at the theater 🎭 before the show. 

Glad I asked, because I was given access to sketch for 2.5 hours in between shows! 🤩

There is of course the spectacle of seeing all the lights on during the show, but seeing the theater shut down was such a lovely experience. 

I saw so many details & moments that I’m sure I would have missed otherwise: the carpentry of the windmill, the stack of playbills on the floor, and windmills carved into the gilded parts of the theater in between cherubs. 

With just 2.5 hours I did a blitz around the theater and then settled on a place to sketch. (Reel and posts coming soon!) 

As I sketched, there was a crew with leaf 🍃 blowers, cleaning up the all the confetti from the end of the show. (Swipe to see me sketching) 

The best part is that about 45 min. before I was supposed to leave, they started testing all the lights, moving around set pieces, and a bunch of actors came on the stage to rehearse a few dance moves. (No, Aaron Tveit was not there, 😭don’t remind me) 

(Swipe to the last video, you can see a bit of the lights changing in the upper left corner.) 

Seeing everything up close of the set design with all the tiny details so lovingly applied, was enough for me to want to drop my art career and go to school for stage design. 😂

@derekmclane was the stage designer for Moulin Rouge, so much admiration for his work! Now that is someone who’s brain 🧠 I would love to pick🤩.

(imagine what it takes to construct and engineer everything to make it functional and practical!!!😱) 

Many people assume that because I’m an artist, I can only be inspired by other artists and art books. 

Nope! In fact, it’s sometimes easier to “see” inspiration when it’s not in the language that you are used to. 

Thanks so much to the folks at @moulinrougebway for letting me sketch, it was one of the most special moments of my career. ❤️
.
.
.
#moulinrouge #moulinrougebroadway #moulinrougemusical #moulinrougethemusical #moulinrougebway

This @moulinrougebway painting is heavily layered, with many different media. In my head I think about it as a crepe cake! 

Each area is different, but an example of a layering sequence would be: 

💚pencil
💚colored pencil & wash
💚acrylic inks 
💚acrylic paint
💚colored pencil again
💚bling
💚acrylics painted on the bling 

With so many materials layering is very important to keep the painting cohesive, so that a specific media doesn’t stick out too much. 

What’s your favorite detail? 😀

Ask me anythjng about my technique in the comments!

People talk about true love, but when your husband willingly poses for a photo 📸so you can paint @derek_klena’s hand better, that’s a whole other level of commitment altogether! 😂

Here’s a sampling of references I found or shot myself, some of which I had to dig very deep to find. (There is one photo my husband shot of my hand, for green fairy on the left of the painting) 

Thankfully there was a short video 🎞️about the costume design, so I was able to get screenshots. It’s rare that I will find a reference photo online that has good resolution, which is why I shoot my own photos as much as I can. 

Satine’s necklace 💎gave me a lot of grief, that blurry screenshot was all I had to work with! 

Yes I did tint water in a glass with that lime green as a stand in for a glass of absinthe. 😂The things we do for our art! 

The curtains a the top are photos I shot at the theater 🎭 when I sketched there. Thank goodness I had that opportunity, I don’t think I would have added the curtains otherwise. 

This is a small fraction of reference I had to gather! I often feel like I’m on some archeological hunt, and at a certain point you just have to deal the scraps you scrounge for. 😆

I’m still very much obsessed with @moulinrougebway, but after the week I have had, I needed to sketch something new! 

I’ve been hearing about @sweeneytoddbway here and there! Actually, my earliest encounter with Sweeney Todd were TV 📺 commercials that advertised the 1982 show with Angela Langsbury. 

I have no idea why I have a crystal 💎clear memory of Angela Langsbury’s neck and hair as she belted out a song with so much fierceness. 

Thanks to Tik Tok (which I now love because it brought me to Aaron Tveit!!😍)I stumbled upon a video of @joshgroban and Kelly Clarkson singing together. 😆

Tell me in the comments if you have seen the show! 

Image reference was a screenshot I took from a video from @cbssundaymorning featuring an interview with Josh Groban. 

I think this is about a 10 min sketch, suuuuuuper sloppy and fast! To get my mind off other things. 💪

Materials are brush pen on a crappy sketchbook that I regret buying at Walmart. (I was stuck in Southern Utah at the time, no other options!)

I taught in the RISD illustration department for many years, have a BFA in illustration, and yet this is my first time really making a concerted effort at freelance illustration. 😆

I made a very pathetic attempt at freelance illustration for about 5 min right after I graduated in 1998. I guess because that’s what I thought I had to do? (For none of the right reasons!) 

I had no clue what I wanted to do, and thought to myself “I like portraits, uh…. I guess I can do that.” So lame!!! 

Which is why I’m baffled that so many of my former students are knocking it out the park in illustration just a few years out of art school! 🤯

Then again, there was no Instagram at the time. Our only way to get in touch with art directors was buying this hard copy book “children’s writer’s and illustrator’s market” that was published once a year, and snail mailing postcards. 

You kids have no idea how easy you have it 😂( not at all, everything is SO oversaturated now!!)

After doing all the Moulin Rouge fan art, I can narrow it down to: “I have a painterly gestural style. My subjects are theatrical, romantic, and grotesque, with an emphasis on the performing arts.” 

Wow that sounds a lot better! 😂 Back then, I also had no idea what supplies to use.  I had a baby printmaking press and thought I would make drypoints. 

The reasoning behind this choice I don’t think ever existed. (and, didn’t offer color as an option which is a huge limitation for illustrators) 

I have a specific technique with acrylic inks and paints that feels very solid after all those Aaron Tveit paintings. 

A loooooooot of imposter syndrome, especially when I see that many of the illustrators and the art directors  in publications are a good 15 years younger than me. Lucky for me, I’m old and don’t care. 😆

I can’t have a portfolio that is 100% Moulin Rouge, so I’m going back to drawings I did on @art.prof live streams and finishing them. 

The prompt here was “Steve Buscemi as a monster.” Swipe to see the earlier version and the reference photo.

Media is oil pastel, I used a mix of Sennelier and Caran d’Ache on grey paper

I’m so grateful to @moulinrougebway for granting me access to the Al Hirschfeld theater in between shows! 

It’s one thing to see the house lights in their full glory, it’s another to get to see the craftsmanship and care that is invested in the stage design up close. 

I recently bought @derekmclane’s incredible book “Designing Broadway” and have been absorbed in it recently. Not only are their stunning photographs of the sets, but Derek McClane includes many sketches of his own, and other stage designers. 

I’m trying to understand how stage design exists within the art world. It’s a unique combination of architecture, interior design, painting, lighting, on some occasions projects and furniture design, and much more. 

In many of the passages they talk about the space as being another character in the show, and how the set design tells the story the show based on the story structure, types of physical movements the actors take, and more. 

I got a small glimpse of that as they were testing lights and moving around the set pieces as I sketched at the theater. 🤯

My time there was very limited, only 2.5 hours, but those drapes did end up in the commission! (Albeit stretched and resized in Photoshop.)

I really do believe that everything me make as artists counts, ultimately, it’s all going to the same place. 

.
.
.
#moulinrouge #moulinrougebroadway #moulinrougemusical #moulinrougethemusical #alhirschfeldtheatre #alhirschfeldtheater #broadway #broadwaymusicals #broadwaytheatre #broadwaytheater

My heart was racing when I sat down to do this marker sketch at the Al Hirschfeld theater 🎭 in between the matinee and evening performance. 

(See the process in the previous reel post) 

Usually when I make artwork I can really take my time and let the artwork set it’s own pace. ⏱️

I only had 2.5 hours, so I sketched furiously to the point that can barely remember what was going through my head. (Rare for me!) 

If there is a genre of panick-drawing 😳this was definitely it! 

In my head, this really wasn’t about getting a great drawing, it was about developing a greater understanding of @moulinrougebway in terms of its creative process. 

People often think drawing is about getting a polished, finished drawing. For me, that’s rarely the case! (I think I would be very stressed out trying to fulfill expectations like that) 

Drawing is a form of seeing, people think it’s all about what your hand is doing, but that’s only half the battle.

The time that I spent observing the theater up close was just as important, if not more, than making this marker sketch. 

In a lot of ways, I feel like this marker sketch was the “leftovers” of this experience. I remember the theater better than what was happening as I sketched! 😆

Sometimes I go into my process knowing what direction I want to go in, other times an idea pops out of the blue. 

When I saw this photo of @yvettenacer, shot by 📸@abrunkus, inspiration struck! 🤩

The joy, gesture, and expression ❤️ in Yvette’s face that @abrunkus captured was so striking and lovely, I had to pick up my brushes. 

@yvettenacer is Satine 💎in the @moulinrougebway National tour, which is currently playing at Washington DC. I’m really sad I can’t go see her perform!!😭

I used several other reference photos: for Yvette’s hair, and for the dress I looked at other people who have performed Satine to get the right visual info. (Omg the dress is going to be soooo tough to paint 😳) 

Plus, my entire illustration portfolio can’t be ALL @aarontveit😆, and yes I DID GET TIX TO HIS CONCERT NEXT YEAR 🤯🤯🤯

I totally skipped the thumbnail sketching process, I’ll be so spontaneous and free this time! 😂

Well, now I’m paying for it, tryjng to figure out the placement of the figure within the background, and of course, cropping at a weird place that won’t fit any standard sizes 🤣

Who is your fav Satine 💎? I looooooved seeing @iamjojo in NYC, and wish I could see them all!!!!!

The art history nerd 🤓 in me has been looking for a way to connect my @moulinrougebway art more deeply to Toulouse-Lautrec who made artworks of the Moulin Rouge in the late 1800’s. 🇫🇷

Art history is full of art portraying performers: John Singer Sargent’s charcoal portrait of Nijinsky 🩰, Caravaggio’s lute players, Aaron Douglas’ paintings of jazz musicians. 🎷

It’s one thing to appreciate an artwork, it’s another thing to feel like you truly understand the artist’s motivation. 

I knew about Toulouse-Lautrec when I was a teenager, so I’ve become very familiar with his work over the decades. 

I love his paintings of singer 🎶Yvette Guilbert, yet never in my life as an artist have I ever had had any desire to paint a performer. 

Until… @aarontveit 🔥🔥🔥and now, @yvettenacer, who gave me an incredible burst of inspiration that led to this painting. ❤️

(📸Photo credit to @abrunkus!) 

The best way I can explain it is, “I GET it now!!!” I feel like I truly understand Toulouse Lautrec’s fascination with the Moulin Rouge and it’s performers. 

Tysm @yvettenacer for your impact on my creative process!! ❤️❤️❤️

See my painting process in the previous reel. 

Materials: acrylic ink and paint, marker, and rhinestone stickers. (Yes, I added pearls to the border, took them off, and added new bling 💎with another trip to Michael’s 😆)

Brownie points if you can identify the plushie on top of the skull in the back.🤩Hint: 🇯🇵

Watch the full ART FIGHT video on Gustave Courbet’s Desperate Man on the @art.prof YouTube.

I’ve been working to expand the range of images for a freelance illustration portfolio. 

I’ve decided to focus on portraiture. I’m hoping I can specialize eventually in portraits of the performing arts 🎭, but I have to start broader at first. 

As much as I would like to only paint Aaron Tveit portraits “until the end of time”😂 (MR people will know what those quotes are for) I can’t have an entire portfolio of Moulin Rouge portraits! 

I went back to this acrylic portrait I started on an @art.prof live stream a looooooong time ago where we were painting portraits from Squid Game. 🦑

On a live stream I don’t do any sketches or planning in advance. In a painting stream we focus more on the painting technique, brushwork, etc. 

(We do have live demos of sketching and thumbnails that focus that planning process) 

I had gotten these Sennelier abstract acrylic paints from the company, so I focused on getting to know those paints. 🎨

Live streams are a great place for me to try something totally outside of what I usually do, so I dove into this fluorescent PINCK (for the tveitor tots 🤣😍) for the highlights on the face. (Swipe to see where I ended in the live stream) 

Picking up an old piece always feels easier, you don’t have to start from scratch! 

I cropped the composition, added way more articulation and texture to the mouth, and ended up some digital tweaks to pump up the darks and saturation of the pink. 

When I was an illustration major in art school, I remember one of the things that really distinguished illustration from painting was that the finished illustration is considered to be the illustration in its context.

Seeing the illustration in a magazine is the finished illustration, not the original painting. 

Boy did that come in handy here! The fluorescent pink was so finicky and it dried almost a different color. I had to photograph 📸 it while it was still wet to get the color I wanted. 

In case you’re wondering, I like some of these acrylics but the fluorescent paint was soooooo wimpy and thin!

Finally got going on my Enjolras painting with @aarontveit 😍! Hottest French 🇫🇷revolutionary who ever existed 🥰

Who here is an Enjolras and/or Les Mis fan? Les Mis is nostalgic for me, I was sooooo obsessed when I was 12! 

This is the first stage: creating digital collages to figure out how to blend together several reference photos to create the scene I want. 

There’s a limit to what Google images can provide, so I rely way more on screenshots I take from videos (too bad for me, gotta watch more Enjolras footage 😘) 

I’m merging the barricade scene from the musical with Enjolras in the film. The musical has thjs incredible atmosphere and lighting that just isn’t present in the movie. 

I love this Enjolras pose, he’s such a dynamic, strong character so I thought it would be interesting to convey what feels like a more quiet moment with him. 🥰

You can see the entire process, step by step in the @art.prof stream I did today. Up next: thumbnail sketches to flesh out the composition! 
.
.
.

Who here has seen @sweeneytoddbway? 💈I find it odd that this was one of my favorite parts of the show?!?

I’m noticing that one of the most enthralling parts of Broadway 🎭 is the atmosphere of the show, it’s like every show has different air particles! 😆

You bet I ate up the cool atmosphere on the stage vs the warmth of the theater lights. 

Two very different pockets of space existing side by side! 
.

I used to think framing was was inherently boring, just something to put your artwork in. 

I had a wonderful framer back in Boston who convinced me otherwise! I was super conservative, and thought I only wanted the plainest frame possible.

He would throw in a frame that seemed so outrageous, but then actually really contributed to the artworks presence.

So I had him on my mind when I was choosing a frame for my painting of @yvettenacer. ❤️

How cool is it that this frame has a dotted border, just like the rhinestone border in my painting! 

Thanks so much @tannerframes for doing a great job with this piece!! 

They also recommended floating it as I had (of course😆) put the rhinestones too close to the edge of the paper, making a mat really difficult to do.
.
.
.

I love it when my paintings surprise me and go in a direction that I never could have anticipated! 

I saw @derek_klena & @iamjojo in @moulinrougebway 🎭in May, and was blown about by their performance. 

There is such a difference between seeing a photo of a performer and actually having the chance to see them IRL. I absolutely believe that experience completely changes your painting, in a way that enriches your interpretation tremendously. 

I started this painting on an @art.prof live stream with no intention of it being more than a demo sketch.

I don’t usually go back and finish pieces from live stream demos, and if I do, it’s minimal. 

When it comes to Moulin Rouge though, which has taken care over my studio practice, it’s hard for me to leave even a simple sketch alone! 

The more paintings I make, the more I see the vast potential with each one, and this one was no exception.

I guess I have always seen rhinestone 💎stickers as a silly craft supply that I would never use. In retrospect, that’s a ridiculous assumption for me to make about an art supply. 

Materials are markers, acrylic inks, acrylic paint, colored pencil, and rhinestone stickers on Rives BFK paper. 

Reference is from video of a 📸photo shoot by @murphymade and @evzmm from @moulinrougebway

I struggle with how much to separate my projects. 

Between the Bread Fairy 🥖🧚🏻‍♂️ artworks, @clarasartadv, 🌎and Broadway, 🎭 it’s hard to tell if people are confused by this diversity here on social media, or if they like the variety. 

I do artist calls ☎️ at @art.prof, and a common decision I suggest people to make is how to organize all of the various parts of themselves.

Like everything I say, it depends. 😂

I worry that I’m going to totally throw off my audience if I have been posting nothing by Broadway artworks for several months, and then pivot back to Bread Fairy. 🥖🧚🏻‍♂️

(Coming soon: Bread Fairy prints!) 

So I’m here to provide confusion 😁 by posting about my new pipe dream, @clarasartadv, to create a travel + art show for TV/📺 streaming. 

At my age, I saw @art.prof as my “final act,” but apparently not. Fundamentally it’s the same thing, wanting to achieve world domination. 😈

Do you like seeing all of the contrasting projects in one place? Or is it a distraction? 

Images: Guangzhou 🇨🇳, Tokyo 🇯🇵, Lisbon 🇵🇹, Goblin 👺 valley in Southern Utah, 🇺🇸 Mammoth 🦣 Lakes in California. 
.
.
.
#traveler #travelers #travelvlog #travelvlogger

Done! I started this portrait of @annaleighashford as Mrs. Lovett in @sweeneytoddbway on an @art.prof live stream. 

Of course what was supposed to be a painting study ended up coming to a complete finish. 😂Swipe to see the various stages of the painting & the reference photo, which is a screenshot I took from a video. 

When I saw Sweeney Todd in NYC, Annaleigh Ashford TOTALLY stole the show. Her accent, the way she moved on the stage, and her feisty, glorious signing was remarkable. 

I’ve noticed that there are some singers who have such great voices, but they get away with bland acting because of their vocals. 

When you have someone who is BOTH it’s like you had no idea a performance 🎭 could be so good. 

I loved what Annaleigh Ashford said about Mrs. Lovett in an interview: she said Mrs. Lovett is a small business owner, a woman in a man’s world. 

As a woman who is a small business owner, I can relate. 😂 I guess I am “successful” enough that I haven’t taken matters to an extreme like she did. (yet🤣)

I feel like Sweeney Todd is supposed to be the main character, but Annaleigh’s performance almost made Sweeney Todd into a supporting role. 

Annaleigh have a lot of dimension to Mrs. Lovett: on one hand she is an awful person, 🔥🩸but you sort of get it, and sympathize with her situation. Brilliant! 

Materials are mostly watercolor, you can see bits of white acrylic in the highlights on the face, hair, and a sliver of it on the right on the neck. 

The white acrylic is “White 2.0” made by Stuart Semple. I like it because it gets great coverage, and is also more matte than other acrylics. I feel like it’s verging on feeling like tempera paint! (Pricey tho, $30 for a small bottle.) 
.
.
.
.

I always thought @art.prof would be my swan 🦢 song, but now ​@clarasartadv is! I definitely have had a travel 🧳 bug for a while, but I also suspect it has to do with feeling like I want to run away. 

Taking care of two teenagers, running my own business, making sure I keep my insanity is so exhausting. I have learned that I don’t handle stress 😳well, and that I can be very paranoid, always waiting for the other shoe 👞 to drop. 

When things get really bad, I often tell my spouse that I want to run away. 😩I don’t actually want to, but I’m pretty sure that any of you who are parents know have felt this to some degree at some point. 

Traveling 🌎is the one part of my life where I can escape the pressure points in my life and be completely immersed in the present. 

Everything feels so much more vibrant when you can be fully present for something, without a worry lingering in the background. 

(Part of being paranoid is trying to anticipate everything that could go wrong, which means it’s often hard for me to focus on the now.)

When I was at RISD I often had students ask if they could do an independent study with me. I met with them first to hear their project proposal. In a lot of cases, it was clear that their project wasn’t developed enough. 

I often tell students that when their project is too broad and vague, that they might as well say they want to make art “about life.”

The thing is, that’s exactly what I imagine ​⁠@clarasartadv to be about: life, every dimension of life is reflected in every place I go, with every artwork I make. 

Hope you’ll follow along with my pipe dream of making it to a streaming a service.

Feels impossible right now, the same way Art Prof felt in 2014, and we all know how that turned out. 😂

My blood🩸splatter palette and flesh palette, euhhhhh😂! I think Mrs. Lovett from @sweeneytoddbway would appreciate this. 🥧 (played by the magnificent @annaleighashford 🎭

.

Since I’ve painted Mrs. Lovett it feels “wrong” to not paint Sweeney, played by @joshgroban in @sweeneytoddbway. 😆

I had no plans to work on digital sketches for today, but before I knew it, my entire afternoon 🌞was spent on Photoshop. 

The process I’ve created for myself is fast, super easy, and really fun. I actively look forward to it when doing a painting like this. 

I’m finding these digital collages to be essential for creating references to paint from. 🎨

(See every step in the Highlight titled “Josh Groban”) 

What can be tricky though, is making sure the image of the actors you’re portraying isn’t one that is straight from a photographer’s shot. 📸

That gets really tough, it’s not like I can call up Aaron Tveit and ask him to come pose. (Now THAT is an artist’s dream come true 😂, well, at least it’s mine😘) 

I do a “Frankenstein” digital collage off using photos from all difference places. Once it gets translated to the painting, enough has changed (I hope) that it doesn’t become a copyright issue. 

The stages of the digital collages always make me laugh; 😂 apologies to @joshgroban for all the warped versions. 🤪

This is just the beginning, and you bet I’m going to buy a razor so I can get just the right angle🩸. Perhaps I have some red paint splattering in my future as well? 

Stay tuned! My freelance illustration portfolio is now almost not 100% Moulin Rouge. 😆
.
.
.

I started this oil pastel portrait of Nicolas Cage in “Renfield” on an @art.prof live stream. 

Tell me in the comments if you’ve seen Renfield; I rarely like new movies, but this one was so over the top that I loved it.🩸

(To see the live stream, type “art prof Nicolas” into YouTube.) 

Having grown up with Nicolas Cage movies it didn’t occur to me that my teens had no idea who he was when we watched Renfield😂

I’ve only used one stick of white Sennelier oil pastels, I was excited that a generous person in the @artproffamily bought me a full set for the last raffle. 

I had no intention to make this a finished piece, but then I realized this would be a good addition to my freelance illustration portfolio. 

The Sennelier oil pastels are soooooo soft, sticky, and smeary - to a fault. @loribluewolfspirit told me that they are like “drawing with lipstick 💄, which is very accurate. 😂

I do enjoy the texture they create. When a piece breaks off it’s so soft you can’t really hold it in your fingers, so I just push it into the paper and smear it around the surface. 

Next time I’ll do the first few layers with Caran d’Ache oil pastels which are way harder, and so the Sennelier smears at the very end. 

Making a piece 100% Sennelier was frustrating; it’s so soft that when you layer, you end up disrupting the layer underneath it! 

Do you have a fav oil pastel brand? I only started using them for the @art.prof live streams, but now I’m imagining that this could be a style I use in the future for illustration! 
.
.
.
.
#renfield #renfieldmovie #renfield2023 #niccage #niccagemovie #nicolascage

@laurynredwelch told me yesterday that I am a goth who aged eloquently as an artist. 😂😂😂

We were doing an @art.prof stage session in our discord last night. I was talking about feeling like I didn’t have a consistent style, and that my freelance illustration portfolio looked so scatter brained. 😵‍💫

Which is when Lauryn gave this really specific description of what my style was. (I still can’t see it😆) 

Do you feel like you have a style as an artist? I sure don’t! 

I find it comforting that regardless of how far I stray from who I am as an artist, I am somehow still a goth at heart. 🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣 xoxo Clara

I did this drawing of the Bread Fairy’s 🥖🧚🏻‍♂️ “carrot 🥕cloud ☁️” cookies way back in 2021! 

You wouldn’t think that carrots 🥕 would make a very good ingredient for a cookie 🍪. 

I confess that when the Bread Fairy told me about them, they didn’t really sound that appetizing to me. 

How wrong I was! One time she had a huge plate of cookies at brunch for our family, they were supposed to be for dessert. We finished up the entire plate before she even put out the appetizers. 😋

She gets these gigantic carrots at the Mexican market here, grinds them all up into a soft paste, and adds frosting that has the slightest hint of lemon. 🍋

I love that these cookies so sloppy when you put them together. So refreshing amongst all of the carefully manicured cookies that you see everywhere on Instagram.

I think these are probably the softest cookies I’ve ever had in my life. Eating one is truly like biting into a cloud. ☁️

I’ve had these cookies so many times, and yet every single time I bite into one, I’m always surprised over and over again at their deliciousness. 😋

Media is soft pastel on pastelbord, made by Ampersand, 18” x 24.” 

Bread Fairy 🥖🧚🏻‍♂️prints will be available very very soon, stay tuned!!!

My first shot at portraying @aarontveit in @sweeneytoddbway; I have a looooooong ways to go! 

They have only released one photo, not much to work with at this moment. I kept this very simple for that reason and treated this more as an experiment to try new materials and approaches. 

So many people have helped me 🙏🙏🙏with angry 😡 photos of Aaron Tveit, so I’ll be compiling those together as a reference soon. 

(Helpful in that I don’t have to worry about copyright since I “mash” together multiple photos to make my own portrait) 

I did a pass with water soluble brush pen markers, the pushed a wet paper towel over it, which activated the markers to create washes. 

I tried Posca pens for the first time, these are suuuuuuper thick and wide tips. They are paint markers so you can get very opaque with them. 

I was bummed the red marker wasn’t very intense, it was a touch too pink for me! 

Since these are illustrations (where the physical artwork isn’t considered the final piece) I have the option of doing digital tweaks.

I pumped up the saturation to get the intense red I was looking for. I have a feeling I will have many art store trips in the future to buy red art supplies. 😂

Who else here has been cardiac arrest since they made the Aaron and Sutton Foster announcement? 🤯🤯🤯
.
.

I do think there is a lot of value in drawing the same thing over and over again, you can really push yourself to diversify your marks and approach. 

I’ve done 8 sketches of @joshgroban in @sweeneytoddbway 🩸🪒🥧 now, and I am just now starting to get into it! Make me wonder, what would sketch #30 look like? 🤔

How many do you want to see me do? 
.

#sweeneytodd #sweeneytoddthedemonbarberoffleetstreet #sweeneytoddfanart #sweeneytoddmusical #sweeneytoddart #joshgroban #joshgrobanfan #grobanite #grobanites #attendthetale #attendthetaleofsweeneytodd

More @joshgroban @sweeneytoddbway sketches that I did on an @art.prof live stream! 

This is my first time using Posca markers; I had the widest chisel tip, a small chisel tip, and a brush tip. I used a red sharpie for the blood 🩸 too. 

I was surprised that even with those smaller tips, I found myself sticking to the wide chisel tip. 

Using only one marker streamlines the process, and you can’t drawing tightly with that chunky chisel tip. You have not choice but to draw in a bold manner! 

A great example of how we adapt to the tools we are using, and what a tremendous influence they can have on our drawing approach. 

Are there any tools you have used that have impacted you in this way? Another one for me is doing a palette knife painting. (No brushes) 

More to come, this technique is just so much fun! 
.
.
.

As we were pulling the Bread Fairy’s 🥖🧚🏻‍♂️objects to arrange with my prints, it occurred to me that they did a similar thing at the MFA Boston.

There is a Sargent painting there, “The Daughters of Edward Darley Boit” which has the vases in the painting displayed. (Swipe to see) 

The vases in the painting are very dark, immersed into the background so it’s startling to get to see the vases in so much detail, with bright lights on them. 

This comparison is such an excellent example of the artist’s eye. As a viewer, we see the vase as this concrete object, but in the painting, the vases have this almost foreboding quality. 

The Bread Fairy’s Brown Betty post is a very shiny, smooth, defined form. 

I certainly didn’t draw it that way! I wanted it to have a more painterly quality so it would immerse itself into the atmosphere of the drawing. 

(Swipe to see the drawing) 

Do you have personal objects you have made art from?

I took out the original text and added my fav lyric from Roxanne, it feels good to be able to share this piece again. 

ICYMI I went through a legal fiasco 😵‍💫 which led to my shop getting shut down, hence these revisions. See my Highlight titled “ugh” for all the gory details. 

Also, I signed paperwork so I am not allowed to talk about the specifics of what happened FYI. 

Original post: This NEVER happens to me: I am actually thrilled with this painting of @aarontveit in @moulinrougebway ??? 😳

This painting didn’t come out of nowhere though, I spent sooooo long on the previous version with endless thumbnails, ink studies, etc. 

See my “Roxanne” Highlight for all the process photos. 

I see everything from the previous painting as “training” I went through to make this painting. (Tried to convince myself that painting was good, but I knew it wasn’t and was in denial😂)

In my head I imagined that capturing this image would work well with straight acrylic ink with a sumi brush and gestural, washy strokes. 

That didn’t end up being the case, the technique changed so much, but it did capture the intense energy I wanted! 

I sketched with water based brush pen markers, loosened the marker drawing with a water brush (a brush which holds water in it, great for travel) added acrylic ink, then red acrylic paint, and white acrylic around the figure. 

This a good example of why it’s helpful to have a general idea of what you want to accomplish, but to be open to abolishing that entirely. 

I used screenshots from the clip as references, too bad I had to watch this clip of Aaron Tveit over, and over again. 😁

One of my friends once asked me “you don’t do anything halfway, do you?” 

I guess this applies to fan art as well. 😆 Maybe watching Aaron Tveit clips on YouTube the whole time I worked is the magic formula? 😍😘🥰(swipe to see)

I have painted @derek_klena before (see my Green Fairy 🧚 painting) but sketching him from life was such a different experience that I loved so much. 

People might look at the Green Fairy painting and be impressed with the scale, details and glamour. Painting from screenshots and photos, there is an inherent distance between you and the people in the painting. 

This humble sketch won’t dazzle ✨anyone the way that painting did, but some ways, I like this sketch more. 

You absorb so much when you draw someone from life! I still remember the way he would casually put his hand in his pocket with singing, and the relaxed sway he has on stage. 

No photo could ever show you that! 

This sketch might look it’s not much, but to me it has all of those observations I made during the rehearsal in it. 

And yes, I did give him the sketch after the concert, he was so sweet and kind. ❤️ I complimented him on his pianissimo passages in the concert 😂 (pianissimo is so so hard to do well, but people rarely notice because it’s not the loud belting solos) 

Thank you so much to @byuwindsymphony 🎵for giving me permission to sketch during the rehearsal! As a classical musician (oboe, I played jn orchestras 🎻for years) it was lovely to enter that world again. 

Opening video clip is from a @moulinrougebway reel.

These sketches I did of @derek_klena at a rehearsal with the @byuwindsymphony 🎶 probably don’t look like much to most people. 

(Especially the 3rd image 😂) 

To me, drawing is much more than the physical drawing you create. In fact, sometimes I see the physical drawing as “leftovers” of an experience. 

There is a common misconception that to draw a person, they either have to be posing like an artist model, or you have to draw from a photo. Not at all! 

I had 4 sketches that were each a different position Derek would get into while singing. 

Unless someone is throwing a javelin, people will often move, but settle back into various poses. 

When Derek was facing right, I started that drawing. When he turned, I would jump to a drawing that was a front view. 

I would wait for him to get back into one of the 4 poses and jump into whatever drawing matched the pose. 

I tell students that when you draw a person, you need to look 👀 at the person 60% and draw 40%. In this case it’s more like looking 95% and drawing 5%.

I’ve watched videos of Derek, and saw him in Moulin Rouge in NYC, 🎭but this is was an intimate look at his singing that no video could ever capture. 

l noticed that Derek had this gentle sway on stage that was relaxed and warm. He straightens out his pinky while holding the microphone🎤, and slides his hand into his pocket occasionally. 

He tilts his head just a touch back when he is singing a long extended note. 🎵

Those observations were another form of “drawing”imo! Through that process of seeing, I got to absorb so much about Derek’s singing and presence in a unique way. 

I gave him the sketch after the concert and yes, he’s as sweet and dreamy IRL as you can possibly imagine. 🥰 Tysm Derek! I will cherish this experience. ❤️

Tysm @byuwindsymphony for granting me permission to sketch!

Hot cross buns from the Bread Fairy! 🥖🧚 it might sound strange to say that these buns are luscious, but the way that they just melt in your mouth is extraordinary. 😋

I was especially excited about these hot cross buns, because my association with hot cross buns are the packaged ones that you get at the grocery store which most certainly are not fresh.

I’m curious, when you think of hot cross buns what do you think about? For me I tend to think about the song🎵, one of the first songs that I ever learned on the oboe.

My kids always tell me they want something “fresh out of the oven,” to the point that they will tell me to delay baking something to make sure they get it right out of the oven. 😆

One of the things that I really love about her cooking and baking is the “flaws” in terms of her presentation.

Those packaged hot cross buns that I’ve seen in the past always have very perfect crosses on top of them, and every single bun looked exactly the same.

I love that the crosses got super wonky and went all over the place. There’s probably only a few where the cross is super visible and obvious!

So often when I see food posted on social media, it looks so perfectly manicured to true point that it almost looks fake and sterile to me.

While she certainly can make food that is so elegant and immaculate in their presentation, I also really appreciate that she’s able to make that feels humble and loving. ❤️

This was originally a sketch of @aarontveit that I did on an @artproffamily live stream, but I couldn’t leave it alone! 

This is from a New Year’s Eve concert he did a few years back at @54below and let’s just say I… really like his pants 😂🥰

(And yes I am crying inside that I can’t go to the one he is doing this year 😭)

If I took all the time I have spent watching clips from this concert, perhaps I would have a second illustration portfolio😍

While it’s great to draw actors in the context of a gorgeous set design, I do also like how pared down his concerts are. You get to FOCUS 🤣

I used a Posca marker brush tip, I’m still getting used to them. They do create great dry brushing strokes! 

Sometimes I feel like I’m cheating if I got back and add white to clean stuff up. (I mean, look at the first version, there was a LOT to fix!) 

Those minor “cleanup” strokes I did with white acrylic ended up taking over the whole thing, so I gave into this being an acrylic painting 😆

The white acrylic is “White 2.0” made by Stuart Semple. It’s got great opaque coverage (waaaay better than Golden’s wimpy Titanium white) but, it does dry really fast so I always have to be prepared for that. 

Initially I drew his facial expression with a smirk, but since he looked like a creep 😂I painted over it and changed to that intense look he has 🥰

Still a loooooong ways to go, and I need to figure out the background and whether I will add color or not.

Would you like to see me add color, or do you think I should stick with the black and white?

Repost of this Sarah Bernhardt cookie drawing, which is now available in my print shop! Link in profile. 

One of my favorite parts of the drawing process is when I surprise myself, which is one of the reasons I deliberately don’t imagine in my head what I want the drawing to look like. 

(Not only would it not turn out the way I imagined it in my head, but for me, drawing just isn’t fun if I go into it knowing what the results will be!) I had an assumption that since there was so much glitter ✨ in the Sarah Bernhardt cookies that I would need to get gold dust, some fun material to get that effect. 

(Who doesn’t want an excuse to use shiny, mesmerizing art supplies?) The more I worked on this drawing, the more I kept blocking in the shapes of the glitter and sheen and before I knew it, I realized I had done enough that adding literal glitter would actually be disruptive. 

I was surprised by the colors I chose too, the reference images I shot of the cookies made the cookies look really brown, but the longer I looked at the reference photo, the more I saw how many deep dark reds were embedded in the image, as well as a dark, muted blues that could be seen in the reflected light. 

I did a ton of “glazing,” and although that’s more frequently associated with painting (or in digital, adding a transparent layer of a color over everything to make the color more cohesive) what I do with the crayon is essentially the same thing. 

I know it looks like I just put dots everywhere for the glitter, but actually, all of those dots of glitter needed glazes of purple with crayons so the glitter could “sink” into the chocolate. 

I promised myself to really truly take a step back from @art.prof this vacation, and wow it’s sooooooo amazing to spend an entire day on a drawing with no interruptions. 
.
.
.
.

Repost of this guacamole flowers drawing, which is now available in my print shop! Link in profile. 

I’ve been on a roll with these guacamole flowers from the Bread Fairy. 🧚🏻‍♂️ 🥖(my mother in law) 

I started on an @art.prof live studio hangout stream, and liked the new Karin brush markers from @universeofmarkers so much that I decided to do more. 

I never get very far in a live stream, we were only on for 45 min. so I definitely didn’t even get close to finishing. 
 
(To see those sketches, check my prior post) Although I’m all for trying new approaches and taking risks, I do think there is value in simply repeating a process you already did, to see what happens the second time around. 

In the second sketch, I compensated too much for the sketches on the live stream being unfinished. I totally overworked this sketch, lost all my highlights and got waaaaaay too dark, the colors bled into each other and got super muddy. 

(This overworked sketch is the last 3 images in the carousel.) I do like these two opposite experiences: underworked and overworked. 

So when I sat down to do this longer, larger piece (first image) I felt like I had explored all the territory and knew where to push and where to step back. 

I initially wanted to embrace more of the highlights, but once I plunged into the green glass plate there was no going back! 

The Bread Fairy told me that the dish is what’s called “Carnival glass,” that you would win at a state fair by pitching pennies. It’s glass from the Depression era, and her mother had a cabinet full of it. 

She said she would open the cabinet and just hold the carnival glass as a child to savor the beauty. As you can see it’s an intersection of pressed 3D patterns, bright colors, and iridescent colors. 

The combination of all these visuals is so over top that you have to love it. It’s so not my aesthetic at all, and I think it got me to dive into bright colors in a way I haven’t before! 
.
.
.
.

I hear people say all the time things like “wow, that drawing is so detailed, amazing!” 

For sure, details play a significant role in drawing, but they are not as important as you might think, and in some cases can actually take away from the drawing . 

(of course, depends on the drawing and what you are looking to do, this is not always the case) 

In my circumstance, cutting back on the detail made the drawing “breathe” more.  Or maybe it was the eight year break I took in between? 😆

While I don’t have any experience with graphic design, I do have plenty experience when it comes to the fundamentals of art. (It makes things just a hair or less intimidating 😆)

One of those fundamentals is shape. 🔵🔶🟩Often times shape is such a simple, basic concept. 

We take it for granted and hardly ever take the time to really think about it deliberately.

Shape can be incredibly powerful visually and conceptually. In this case, the diamond tells the story of @ladygaga’s character, Harley Quinn in @jokermovie. 

Since I feel so totally out of my element, and overwhelmed by the 5 billion options there are with digital, I decided to pair it all the way down and just think about diamonds.♦️ ♦️♦️

Image 2 is the first one that I did, pretty static. Image 3 is me going totally overboard on purpose in terms of the number of diamonds.

Image 4 is far too simplistic, so I think I have landed on image 1 as being the better balanced composition out of these. 

There’s a temptation when you’re learning something new, to try to tackle everything all at once. I’m trying to resist that by keeping things simple and tackling only a few things at a time.

Also, I am pleased to announce that I know how to use a clipping mask in Photoshop now🤣
.
.
.

There are some cases where I think using digital is a lot more effective and efficient than doing sketches by hand. (still dreaming of an iPad, some day!) 

This is not one of those cases for me. I find this technique that I use to be especially helpful when I want to feel like I have some kind of bridge between a tiny sloppy, thumbnail sketch into a larger drawing.

A sketch like this provides more nuance and detail, it makes me feel like I am closer to the final drawing. That leap from digital into a final traditional drawing can be big one at times that is tough for me to do.

I am such an old fart, I just love the way paper feels! I still can’t read a book on a device, something about turning those physical pages feels better to me. It’s the same thing when it comes to sketches like this for me. 
.
.
.
.

“Only” took 2 years to finish this drawing! 😂I like to tell myself it was “marinating” this whole time. 

It’s been a while (at least a year) since I’ve done any Bread Fairy 🥖🧚🏻‍♂️ artworks. I used to think for a long time that the bodies work that I created had a finish line, a point where I made the decision to end it, and not to go back to that work.

Lately though, more and more, I find myself returning to older bodies of work at random times.

In that sense, I have shifted my mindset to be much more flexible and to think about these bodies of work as continually evolving, sometimes over a period of many years.

I like this a lot more! To think about the bodies of work as almost living breathing organisms.

I’m a different person after a period of time, and I like seeing how that is reflected within the artwork.

Or, maybe I’m just tired of having unfinished work lying around and want to finish it😂

Materials are Caran d’Ache Neocolor I crayons, Faber-Castell Durer watercolor pencils on black watercolor paper by Legion paper.

I never thought I would finish this illustration of @aarontveit in @sweeneytoddbway 💈🩸🪒 but here it is! 🤩

There were so many stages in this drawing! The second image is a super quick marker sketch that I did before the live stream.

Swipe to see all of the various stages of sketching and WIP that I did, and previous reels to learn more. 

As much as I am a major planner, it was really fun to react to what was happening in the drawing , and to find the narrative in there. 

(normally, I would’ve spent a really long time doing all that before I start the final drawing)

Not really what I recommend doing in general, but it was a new experience for me that I enjoyed.

Sweeney Todd has been portrayed so many times, and the typical illustration you’ll see involves lots of razor 🪒 action, blood 🩸, and wild startled, facial expressions.

I liked that this illustration was a less commonly seen moment of the character. Sweeney Todd is someone who begins the show with a tragic history, and part of that was losing his wife. 

Even thought he spends his days murdering people in his barbershop, 💈 I have to imagine that he would also have quiet, intense moments of pain that he would experience alone. 

The downward gaze of his face, the lighting from above, and the hunched shoulders, all contribute to that emotion.

His wife Lucy Barker in the upper left-hand corner is more suggestive and subtle, as I wanted him to be most prominent.

The reference photo I was using (Sorry, I can’t share my reference photos) was extremely blurry, but actually, I liked it that way.

In the reference photo, her face was so simple, it had a ghost-like look. Then the textures of her hair layered over that really pulled me in.

I love it when as an artist I surprise myself, and 2023 was full of that! 

Looking back to the beginning of the year, my Bread Fairy 🥖🧚🏻‍♂️ series was starting to wind down. I did a few printmaking projects, plein air here and there, but was wandering for a bit artistically. 

Then Aaron Tveit and Moulin Rouge came into my life 🥰😍and somehow I’m now an illustrator with a focus on Broadway 🎭 and movie 🍿 posters??? 

I met @derek_klena and @yvettenacer IRL, who brought me so much joy! 🙏❤️

@clarasartadv still feels like pie 🥧 in the sky, but I am proud that this year I created spaces dedicated to this work in a new YouTube channel. 

@clarasartadv isn’t something I can work on all the time, boy is it expensive! (Note that I will hop on a plane ✈️ and go anywhere if someone wants to cover my trip!🤩)

Which is why my trip to Japan 🇯🇵 was pivotal in that it was the first time I created a concrete travel show structure for the content which fleshed out for the first time, how this might work long term. 

My New Year’s resolutions? Make art and keep my kids alive😂 goals are much easier if you set very low standards 🤣

I reeeeeeeeally don’t want to go back and paint this by hand!!!!!! 

Still messing around, any of you digital wizards have ideas for things I could do in Photoshop?

When I need to shoot effective reference photos, I’ll do anything it takes to get what I’m looking for. 😆

Have you ever shot your own reference photos? If yes, I’d love to hear about the odd things you (or your models) had to do to get the right image. 😂

Here’s an instance where you can totally miss the point with an artwork when you can’t experience it in person! 

For me, between all of the various materials, and the scraping, and the thickness of the Dura-Lar, it’s such a completely different experience compared to making a charcoal drawing.

By the way, the Dura-Lar that I used here is not the one you can get in the art stores, which is usually a lot like acetate. 

The lovely manager of the RISD store used to purchase it for me directly from the manufacturer when I used to teach there. The one he got for me is crazy sturdy and strong!

Note: this is not a pro gig! One relationship I’ve never had before is working with an Art Director. 

That relationship seems so opaque online, so I thought it would be fun for us to take away that wall and show you what it’s actually like. 

If I’m going to do freelance Illustration, I need to learn the nuts and bolts of what that relationship is like. Lucky for me, I know a seasoned Creative Director Ashley Browning. 

Ashley is coming on the @art.prof live stream this coming Sunday to talk about how to start learning graphic design.

For that stream, we thought it would be really helpful if she art directed me through the process of designing a movie poster for my portfolio.

This is the first round of thumbnails that I did. I sent them to her with this message, and I’ll share in the next real what she wrote back. 

“Before I send you “real thumbnails” can you tell me if thumbnails that look like this would be acceptable? In terms of format and how sketchy they are. 

Should I include color or just do black and white? I numbered each sketch too. You can see them here 

For mood board images, I dropped a whole bunch here, wasn’t sure if you wanted something that looked more like a mosaic of images 

This folder has everything in it. Lmk if there is a better format for sending images too.” 

Raise your hand if you remember the rack of Cliff Notes books at the store 😆 xoxo Prof Lieu 
.
.

Note: this is not a pro gig! I get a point for meeting the deadline at least! 😂 Below is Ashley’s email: 

“Concepting:
I think for thumbnails we should start seeing what themes we can extract. So what I see is concept #1 would focus more on a singular character. 

concept #2 use negative space and landscape elements to visually portray the vastness of the world, and concept #3 (isn’t developed but would be nice to have) 

How can we incorporate multiple elements of the film (i.e. the “good guys vs bad guys” or man vs. the desert or some of the technology aspects along side a human character or landscape) 

Moving forward, have all of your thumbnails fall into one of these 3 buckets. 

Thumbnail Execution:

- Please double check your dimension ratios. Some of your thumbnails are shorter than others which will affect how I will digitally lay them outs 

- Leave room for the type in your layout. You can rough in the title which would be very helpful. 

When roughing in the title, be mindful that the Dune brand has a font which we should adhere too.

Also keep in mind that we will need space for the name of actors and maybe teaser copy. Please leave appropriate negative space to accommodate this. 

- I noticed you had artwork notes inside some of the thumbnails. Please only include text that will be in the layout within the thumbnails. You can write your notes to the side. 

- Try to play with the scale of how the type interacts with the image. We can create the sense of vastness with the type and whitespace in the composition. 

I can finesse this for you in the rough stage but I would like to see an earnest attempt at this. 

- Try to keep your thumbnails in grayscale. At this stage we should be thinking about layout, shape and how different overall concepts communicate to the consumer. 

Action Items:

- Create 3-5 thumbnails per each concept to review. (if you have another concept you’d like to explore please do the same amount of thumbs for that as well)

After you get the next round of thumbnails I’ll pick the ones I find are the strongest and go over feedback with you. 

Ideally I would like to see the next round of thumbnails by Tuesday AM.”

This is not a pro gig! I’m practicing with a seasoned Creative Director, Ashley Browning on how an illustrator would work with them. 

I’m doing a movie poster for the Dune 2 movie, and boy were my first round of thumbnail sketches a hot mess! 

Which is why I was SO grateful for Ashley’s concrete, specific feedback. I spend all day teaching people fundamentals on shape, and yet I couldn’t do it myself. 😂

I felt sooo much better with this round of thumbnails. Stay tuned to see the more refined thumbnails I did next in pencil, coming soon! xoxo Prof Lieu

I know some people have said to me that they feel like they wouldn’t be able to take the amount of feedback that I’m getting from my Art Director, but for me, I absolutely love it!

Since I own my own business at @art.prof, I am basically in charge of everything. So to know that somebody else is directing me, and telling me what to do, is actually quite refreshing.😂

You wouldn’t think that thumbnail sketches, as simple as they are, might need a specific set art supplies. 

It even depends on the type of thumbnail you’re doing; those shape based thumbnails I did with only Tombow brush pen markers since gradients didn’t matter.

I switched over to pencils for more refined sketches. Since the sketches are small, out of the three erasers I used, I found myself using the Generals Factis BM-2 eraser pencil most of the time. 

Other supplies here are a kneaded eraser, a Faber-Castell dust free eraser, 2B and B pencils, blue painter’s tape, an aluminum tray, and grey paper to make the viewfinder with the correct aspect ratios. 

(Plus a ruler and triangle to measure out the viewfinder)

.

Here’s a side-by-side comparison of the screenshot from the video with the artist model, and the figure drawing that I did from it.

You can see a clip from the video that we shot in the second image here.

In someways, I feel like a reference image that is blurry is more exciting to work with. Because there is no detail, you have to think about the essential structure of your subject.

You also have to invent more when your reference photo is so blurry. You’ll see in these comparisons that a lot changes from the screenshot into the drawing. 

Having blurry photos, almost feels like a lump of clay that I can manipulate more dramatically.

Materials are Korn’s lithographic rubbing ink on Strathmore charcoal paper. The charcoal paper has a texture to it, which I think led itself well to this imagery.

The lithographic rubbing ink is like the world’s most intense, dark, sticky, drawing material you can imagine.  You feel like you are drawing with tar! 

It’s a big chunk, looks like a candy bar, and is even  wrapped in tinfoil! You can get it in various hardnesses, but I really like the soft kind which pushes itself more easily on the surface.

It seems like more and more, I am revisiting my old work. People were asking me about my process for these, which is why I made the reels. 

However watching the video through for the first time in years, it makes me think that maybe there is new work to be made here? 

I remember thinking at the time that the four years I spent on this project was such a marathon. Continuing it 12 years later, makes me think that this is a project that isn’t going to have an ending anymore.

I suppose these drawings are somewhat of a ‘“reenactment” of the drawings that I did way back in 2011.

A lot of you have been asking me questions about the process for creating these drawings, which is why I revisited them to make reels.

But what’s interesting is how even though I’m using the same process and materials, these three new drawings that I did last night really do feel quite different. (I guess that’s inevitable.)

I noticed that in the drawings that I did in 2011, there was a lot less articulation of the form, and there were more eraser marks that were pushing through the figure across the form.

These drawings, I didn’t quite take the same approach. I used the same technique of pushing the lithographic rubbing ink across the paper with the Staedtler Mars plastic eraser.

But what’s different is that I was thinking a lot more about the anatomy and really getting the volume of the form. 

I was worried that if I spent too much time thinking about the anatomy, that it will not be expressive enough. The lithographic  rubbing ink though is such an awkward tool because it’s so large, so that that’s really not possible here.

I find with these sketches that I always have to do several before I find one that I think is working. Last night I did three sketches, the first one is an absolute car crash! (Image 8) 

The second one (image 9) was a little bit too aggressive and got too dark too fast. The challenge with lithographic rubbing ink is that once it’s on the paper, you really cannot get rid of it. And the brightest you can get it back to the middle gray.

The third drawing (first image) I stepped back a bit, and delayed putting down the dark marks. I think that was a better balance where I was able to get a little bit more control.

Materials are: Strathmore charcoal paper, lithographic rubbing ink, Staedtler mars plastic eraser.

For more information about my process materials, see my recent reels.
